row.entry: Physician, VA Boston HealthCare System, 150 South Huntington Ave Boston, MA 02130
Contractor- Physician Informaticist, Office of Women's Health Services, 8455 Colesville Rd, 12th Floor Silver Spring, MD 20910

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: The VA is committed to improving the ability of clinicians to provide care for patients while increasing quality, safety, and efficiency. Recognizing the importance of standardizing clinical knowledge in support of this goal, VA is implementing the Health Level 7 (HL7) Knowledge Artifact Specification for a wide range of VA clinical use cases. Knowledge Artifacts, referred to as (KNARTs), enable the structuring and encoding of clinical knowledge so the knowledge can be integrated with electronic health records to enable clinical decision support.

The purpose of this Clinical Content White Paper (CCWP) is to capture the clinical context and intent of KNART use cases in sufficient detail to provide the KNART authoring team with the clinical source material to construct the corresponding knowledge artifacts using the HL7 Knowledge Artifact Specification. This paper has been developed using material from a variety of sources: VA artifacts, clinical practice guidelines, evidence in the body of medical literature, and clinical expertise. After reviewing these sources, the material has been synthesized and harmonized under the guidance of VA subject matter experts to reflect clinical intent for this use case.

Unless otherwise noted, items within this white paper (e.g., documentation template fields, orderable items, etc.) are chosen to reflect the clinical intent at the time of creation. To provide an exhaustive list of all possible items and their variations is beyond the scope of this work.

preface.title: Conventions Used
preface.para: Conventions used within the knowledge artifact descriptions include:

listitem.para:
<obtain>: Indicates a prompt to obtain the information listed
If possible, the requested information should be obtained from the underlying system(s). Otherwise, prompting the user for information may be required
The technical and clinical notes associated with a section should be consulted for specific constraints on the information (e.g., time-frame, patient interview, etc.)
Default Values: Unless otherwise noted, <obtain> indicates to obtain the most recent observation. It is recognized that this default time-frame value may be altered by future implementations
[...]: Square brackets enclose explanatory text that indicates some action on the part of the user, or general guidance to the clinical or technical teams. Examples include, but are not limited to:
[Begin ...], [End ...]: Indicates the start and end of specific areas to clearly delineate them for technical purposes.
[Activate ...]: Initiates another knowledge artifact or knowledge artifact section.
[Section Prompt: ...]: If this section is applicable, then the following prompt should be displayed to the user.
[Section Selection Behavior: ...]: Indicates technical constraints or considerations for the selection of items owithin the section.
[Attach: ...]: Indicates that the specified item should be attached to the documentation template if available.
[Link: ...]: Indicates that rather than attaching an item, a link should be included in the documentation template.
[Clinical Comment: ...]: Indicates clinical rationale or guidance.
[Technical Note: ...]: Indicates technical considerations or notes.
[If ...]: Indicates the beginning of a conditional section.
[Else, ...]: Indicates the beginning of the alternative branch of a conditional section.
[End if ...]: Indicates the end of a conditional section.
☐ [Check boxes]: Indicate items that should be selected based upon the section selection behavior.

section.title: Clinical Context
section.para: Annual well woman visits provide an important opportunity for providers to identify health risks, screen for conditions, provide preventive care, and counsel patients. Well woman visits should include guideline-based evaluations and services based on individual and age-related risk factors. These visits consist of four components: screening, testing, evaluation and counseling, and immunizations [(The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) 2017].

This Well-Woman documentation template is required to be bundled with the Reproductive Health documentation template in order to capture and document comprehensive information collected during a well-woman visit.

[Clinical Comment: Clinical Comment: The Well-Woman Visit Documentation Template is intended to allow for guidelines-based efficient documentation of a well-woman visit, stratified by age category. Well visits, as opposed to visits that focus on acute and and/or chronic conditions, focus on preventive care and include the clinical provider taking a medical history of the patient, performing a history-based physical exam, conducting guideline-based preventive care according to age, ensuring that immunizations are current, and providing education and counseling.]

row.entry: Provider to include Primary Care, Gynecologists, and designated Women's Health clinical providers to include Allied Health Professionals
Female that is at least 13 years of age or older
Primary Care, Gynecology, and Women's Health Services

section.title: Knowledge Artifacts
section.para: The CDS knowledge artifact that defines this clinical use case is described in detail in the following sections and includes:

listitem.para:
Women's Health: Well-Woman Visit - Documentation Template KNART
Provides a guide for documenting the appropriate information for collection during a well-woman visit
Includes logic for the appropriate display of the documentation sections
Link to Women's Health: Reproductive Health - Documentation Template KNART

chapter.title: Women's Health: Well-Woman Visit Documentation Template
chapter.para: [Begin Women’s Health: Well-Woman Visit Documentation Template.]

section.title: Knowledge Narrative
section.para:
[Technical Note: The Documentation template shall:
Allow for the efficient documentation of a well woman visit.
Adjust content presented to the clinician based on the age and risk factors of the individual patient, displaying only those items appropriate for that patient.
3. Integrate or link corresponding KNART documentation templates, Event Condition Action (ECA) rules, and order-sets for the items that are reusable across content.
Pre-populate with existing data from the patient’s electronic medical record for review and editing by the clinical provider.]

section.title: Well-Woman Visit
section.para: [Technical Note: The template will be structured as follows, with components appropriate to the patient’s age and risks. (See Appendix A for age-stratification of each of the components.)]

[Technical Note: The clinical provider will be presented only with the documentation template section that is appropriate for the patient's age. The data elements for each age-specific category are listed below for review and authoring purposes.]

section.title: Age >=13 years old to <19 years old
section.para: [Begin Age >=13 years old to <19 years old.]
[Technical Note: This section should be provided for patients who are >=13 years old to <19 years old.]

section.title: History
section.para: [Technical Note: Information that can be obtained from the electronic medical record should pre-populate the template fields in a manner that is apparent to the clinical provider.]

[Section Prompt: Menstrual History.]
[Section Prompt: Age of Menarche?]

[Section Prompt: Date of Last Menstrual Period (LMP)?]

section.title: Testing
section.para: [Section Prompt: ACOG recommends testing of all adolescents who are sexually active.]
[Section Selection Behavior: Select one or more. Optional.]
[Section Selection Behavior: Select one or more. Optional.]

listitem.para: ☐ 75-g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) with 2-Hour Plasma Glucose (2-h PG
[Section Prompt: Colorectal Cancer Screening is indicated for patients with family history of familial adenomatous polyposis or 8 years after the start of pancolitis.]
[Technical Note: Link to Colorectal Cancer Screening KNART.]
[Section Prompt: Genetic Counseling/Testing is indicated based on personal risk factors.]

listitem.para: [Technical Note: Body mass index (BMI) should be calculated and provided above in kilograms per square meter (kg/m2), using the formula BMI = 703 × weight (pounds)/height (inches)^2.]
<obtain> Other Physical Exams (as Indicated by History)

section.title: Testing

listitem.para: [Technical Note: Link to Cervical Cancer Screening KNART.]

☐ Colorectal Cancer Screening
[Section Prompt: Begin screening at age 50 years.]
[Technical Note: Link to Colorectal Cancer Screening KNART.]

☐ Breast Cancer Screening
[Technical Note: Link to Breast Cancer Screening KNART.]

☐ Diabetes Testing
[Section Prompt : Beginning at age 45 years, consider diabetic screening every three years. Diabetic screening is not indicated for those patients with average risk and less than 45 years of age; or patients with known diagnosis of diabetes mellitus; or who have been screened within the last 3 years; or other reason indicated by patient care provider.]
☐ Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG)
☐ 75-g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) with 2-Hour Plasma Glucose (2-h PG)
☐ Hemoglobin A1c

☐ Lipid Panel
[Section Prompt : Beginning at age 45 years, consider performing lipid panel every five years. For those women less than 45 years of age, lipid panel is not indicated if average risk; or for those who have been screened within the last 5 years; or other reason indicated by patient care provider.]

☐ Hepatitis C Virus
[Section Prompt: One-time Hepatitis C virus testing indicated for persons born from 1945 through 1965 and unaware of their infection status.]
<obtain> Hepatitis C Virus results

section.para:
[Section Prompt: Chlamydia and Gonorrhea Testing.]
[Section Prompt: Chlamydia and Gonorrhea testing is not indicated in patients who are low risk, who have never been sexually active, or other reason indicated by patient care provider.]

[Section Selection Behavior: Select one or both. Optional.]
☐ Chlamydia
☐ Gonorrhea

[Section Selection Behavior: Select one or more. Optional.]
☐ Human Immunodeficiency Virus HIV
☐ Tuberculosis (TB) Skin Test
☐ Hemoglobin Level
☐ Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
☐ Genetic Counseling/Testing
[Section Prompt: Consider Genetic Counseling/Testing in patients with fragile X syndrome, Tay-Sachs disease, or if there is a concern about cystic fibrosis carrier status or spinal muscular atrophy. Also, assess for risk of a hemoglobinopathy for women considering pregnancy.]
<obtain> Test(s)
☐ Bone Mineral Density Screening
[Technical Note: Link to Osteoporosis Screening KNART.]

[Section Prompt: Good Health Practices/Risk Assessment Counseling provided.]
☐ Aspirin prophylaxis
[Section Prompt: For women age 50-59 years, consider if not at an increased risk for bleeding, have a life expectancy of at least 10 years, and are willing to take low-dose aspirin daily for at least 10 years. For women age 60-64 years, prophylaxis decision should be individualized based on no known increased risk for bleeding, and a life expectancy of at least 10 years.]
☐ Chemoprophylaxis for Breast Cancer
[Section Prompt: Chemoprophylaxis for breast cancer may be indicated for high risk women 35 years or older.]
☐ Hormone Therapy
☐ Hygiene
☐ Dental Care

appendix.title: Reference Tables
appendix.para: [Clinical comment: The following tables were developed based on content on the ACOG website: https://www.acog.org/About-ACOG/ACOG-Departments/Annual-Womens-Health-Care/Well-Woman-Recommendations and are intended to be used to verify the content with the Clinical Content White Paper.

table.title: Reference Table for Screening Activities Related to Patient History

row.entry: Section of Well-women Visit Documentation Template
Preconception counseling - link to Reproductive Health KNART

entry.para: - Substance Abuse (include tobacco, alcohol, opioids and other drugs),

listitem.para: Sexual practices include vaginal, anal, and oral sex; sexual orientation; number of partners; and exchange sex for drugs or money.

table.title: Reference Table for Screening Activities Related to Physical Exam

row.entry: Section of Well-Woman Vist Documentation Template
Breast exam as indicated by history
Other physical exams (as indicated by history)

table.title: Reference Table for Laboratory and Other Testing: Periodic and Risk-Based

row.entry: Section of Well-Woman Visit Documentation Template
Every five years cytology with HPV co-testing preferred; every 3 years if cytology alone
Stop screening if the woman has adequate negative prior screening results[1] and no history of CIN2 or higher
61-74 biennial; 75 and older life offer biennial if life expectancy is 10 or more years
Per CDC and state guidelines https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5514a1.htm Put in high risk testing section
Per CDC and state guidelines https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5514a1.htm Put in high risk testing section
If family history of familial adenomatous polyposis or 8 years after the start of pancolitis
Begin at age 45 years (If tests are normal, repeat testing carried out at a minimum of 3-year intervals is reasonable)
Cystic fibrosis carrier status, spinal muscular atrophy, and assess for risk of a hemoglobinopathy for women considering pregnancy; or patients with fragile X syndrome, Tay-Sachs disease
Cystic fibrosis carrier status, spinal muscular atrophy, and assess for risk of a hemoglobinopathy for women considering pregnancy; or patients with fragile X syndrome, Tay-Sachs disease
Hepatitis C virus testing - one-time testing for persons born from 1945 through 1965 who haven’t been tested
Hepatitis C virus testing - one-time testing for persons born from 1945 through 1965 who haven’t been tested

listitem.para: Adequate negative prior screening results are defined as 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results within the previous 10 years, with the most recent test performed within the past 5 years.
Note state regulations vary and should be incorporated into a template by the organization implementing the template.

table.title: Reference Table for Counseling and Education

row.entry: Section of Well-Woman Visit Documentation Template
Safe Sexual practices including barrier protection
High risk sexual behaviors, STIs and barrier protection, acquaintance rape prevention.
Abuse: sexual, physical, emotional, and bullying by partner, family members, peers
Neglect and abuse: sexual, physical, intimate partner violence
Personal history of preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, or pregnancy induced hypertension

In women age 50-59 who are not at an increased risk for bleeding, have a life expectancy of at least 10 years, and are willing to take low-dose aspirin daily for at least 10 years. 60-64 individualized based on no known increased risk for bleeding, and a life expectancy of at least 10 years.
65 – 69 individualized based on no known increased risk for bleeding, and a life expectancy of at least 10 years
35 and old for high risk women
Safe driving practices including texting while driving, driving under the influence, seat belt use
Substance use/abuse: tobacco, alcohol, opioids and other drugs

listitem.para: Aspirin prophylaxis for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and colorectal cancer (CRC) in those who have a 10% or greater 10-year CVD risk.

row.entry: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
